body:
Hi @amatiushkin - I'm curious as to what is behind your question. Does it affect you?

See [JENA-1997|https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JENA-1997] the ticket that gives some background.

To be clear: The proper writer is in jena/ARQ/RIOT.

The old (jena-core) is writer isn't compliant with the RDF 1.1 Turtle space. It is not accessible unless:
- the app uses jena-core only
- the app reconfigures the internal RIOT wiring in unsupported ways

And it isn't N3, and never was, despite its name.

If you are interested in developing N3 support, Jena does have th enecessary RDF term extension `Node_Graph` for representing N3 formulae.

@afs I was looking for API to parse input on older version 3.15-ish and then discovered this change which got me puzzled. 

Now I have more context, so it is all good.

`RDFDataMgr` for most tasks for read and write.

Then `RDFparser` and `RDFWriter` and their builders, for detailed control and setup.
There will be a separate PR branched on this one for changes to abstract the IRI and establish the contract between IRI implement provider and the rest of Jena.

This is an unfinished draft.

See the package "irix" (this is a temporary location).
The basic interface looks fine as far as I'm able to pick it out amongst the swathe of related changes

This is now complete. There is further checking that can be done which is why it'll be "draft" for awhile.

`jena-iri` is still used directly in the XML I/O, `jena-jdbc-core` and cmds for IRI validation. Those can wait if they need changing at all.

Almost inevitably, from going through all the code, reviewing the parser tests, and generally going back to look at old code,

Only http, urn and file URIs have scheme specific checking.

**Change 1**

Bad percent encoding e.g. `http://example/abc%XZdef` is strictly a syntax error in RFC 3986, not merely bad practice. In the changes here, it becomes an error.

There are no warnings for lowercase (upper case is recommended, but not required).

**Change 2**

URN handling: RFC 8141 tightens up the rules on URNs to be urn:NID:NSS, NID is at least 2 alphanumerics, and NSS at least one. This is more restrictive that the previous RFC 2141 which allowed NID to be "X-"

A consequence is that using `urn:NID:` as a prefix is strictly an illegal URN but Jena accepted it.

`urn:x:` was never legal but Jena accepted it and I would not be surprised if it is used in Jena users test data. It was in Jena although now that's all cleaned up and the Jena test suite passes in strict URI mode.

Currently, the default is to run with only light checking of URN specific rules.

Here is a list of links:

URI: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986
HTTP:     https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7230
URN:      https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc8141
UUID:     https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4122 (as urn:uuid:)
DID:      https://www.w3.org/TR/did-core/
file:     https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc8089#section-2

URI scheme registry: https://www.iana.org/assignments/uri-schemes/uri-schemes.xhtml
URN namespace registry:  https://www.iana.org/assignments/urn-namespaces/urn-namespaces.xhtml

Performance: pure parsing costs. (light test)

Test: Running "riot" with 4 BSBM 25 million .nt.gz in one run of the program (the argument being the first time warms the JVM; in fact the numbers don't show any effect). File has been used previously so in the file system cache.

Jena 3.17.0 and Jena+thisPR are within 0.5% of each other which is less than the timing variance.

Jena+PR with the [new IRI parser](https://github.com/afs/iri4ld/) is at least 12% faster. I'm surprised it's measurable.

@dependabot ignore this major version

Switched off:
- Jetty 10.0.0 depends on Java11 and the project does not want to loose the ability to go back to Java8 until the impact of Java11 on Jena users is clear.
- Probably then want to jump to jetty11, which is the same as jetty 10, but with `javax.*` packages becoming `jakarta.*`
OK, I won't notify you about version 10.x.x again, unless you re-open this PR or update to a 10.x.x release yourself.
@dependabot recreate
JENA-2033 here to avoid a potential merge conflict because the fix is to a class modified by this PR.
I'll merge just just before jena-text-es is retired.
Thanks!
Used `git cherry-pick`to put the Lucene update commit onto 'main'.

Looking into the Jetty configuration is a bit uck. It's probably quite safe because that has been the way for many versions making it de facto the API.

Exploring alternatives:

A possibility is not support a port of zero and require the app choose one. The tests use `WebLib.choosePort` and explicitly set the port from outside.  Obviously, there is a timing issue that needs recovering by catching the bind exception and retrying. Probably no better than building in the game of "hunt the port" but I thought I'd mention it.

There is `fusekiServer.getJettyServer().getURI.getPort()` though all that does is to iterate to find the first connector that is a `NetworkConnector` in order, i.e. connector zero. and call `getLocalPort()`.

`org.eclipse.jetty.server.Server.getURI` shows how to dig information out of the connectors e.g. https.
Would it be worth adding a unit test (if not yet covered) for the single letter windows partition name? To prevent a regression..

There is a test in `TestJenaReaderRIOT` - it tries all the ways to write file names.

It was `read_url_3` and `read_url_3x` that were failing on the Jenkins windows build.
Wrong JIRA.

Further options:
* Remove promise to return the HTTPS port
* Make use of the way Fuseki initializes Jetty (see JettyHttps::server):
  * there are at most two connectors
  * second one is the HTTPS connector
  but that is error prone and not nice regarding maintainability
* iterate through all connectors

If you go "Files Changed" -> cog -> "Hide Whitespace Changes" it's better. It's still big and not very interesting; more deletions than additions.

We have several downstream projects, some do track dev builds, so we can see if it's OK that way as well.  I've already checked with RDF Delta.

The build does pass.

>If you go "Files Changed" -> cog -> "Hide Whitespace Changes" it's better.

Ah! Today-I-Learned! Thanks @afs !

Comments responded to and fixed in the force-pushed updates. 

Trying to make this a single commit.

Bullet two looks good.

Code can look to see which is protocol a connector provides - returning some "http" and some "https" (and there will be at most one of a protocol in normal use).

https://github.com/eclipse/jetty.project/blob/jetty-10.0.x/jetty-server/src/main/java/org/eclipse/jetty/server/Server.java#L739

(that's 10.x but the 9.x code is the same - sometime Jena will move to Jetty 10 or 11, both require Java11 but we thought we'd let Jena moving to Java11 roll out first)

Looks good.

Would you mind squashing this down to one commit please (it retains your name rather than us squash it which doesn't).

There are mentions of "IRI3986". This is the replacement IRI code (https://github.com/afs/iri4ld) for after 4.0.0. Having the tests helps pin down the functionality. IRI3986 does pass the test suite so jena-iri and IRI3986 agree.

I've squashed this into a single commit, but when I'm trying to run this on my forked repo, I now get a disk full error on the windows build each time, during the tdb tests. I'll debug a bit and see if I can see what quotas the disk has.

TDB (1 and 2) tests can run into issues.  Memory mapped files on MS Windows do not get deleted from the file system until the JVM process exits This is a long standing Java bug.

The tests for Windows try to reuse database but it still leaves a significant over head.

Aslo, any crashes have before left dead directories (JUnit clean up not happening fully?).

If it causes problems, then just have Linux and MacOS - we have MS Windows testing on Jenkins . Adding MacOS to the GH action CI is still a step forward.

I'll remove the `windows-latest` from the matrix then. I didn't manage to change the directory or find a way around it.

It looks like there is 12 GB left for the run on the `D:` volume before running maven. I tried to change some options to use the `c:\ volume`, which has 65 GB free, but no luck. 

https://github.com/OyvindLGjesdal/jena/actions/runs/590467566 contains the latest job with disk info before the run. I see some errors in the build, but mostly "not found". Not sure what that implies.

I had one sucessful run on MacOS, but it also does timeout.

Thanks - merged.

We can see what happens when run in the Apache Software Foundation account.
Requires changes in Jena.

Probably for a follow-up issue, and not a blocker for this PR?

I looked at getting the windows (and macOs) worflow to run/pass earlier, and I think it is related to https://github.com/apache/jena/pull/941
 
With [some changes to timeouts](https://github.com/OyvindLGjesdal/jena/compare/jena-2052-workflow-add-windows-and-dispatch...OyvindLGjesdal:windows-timeout) to the tests, the [windows build passes](https://github.com/OyvindLGjesdal/jena/runs/2017540130?check_suite_focus=true) sometimes, but I'm not sure if the tests are still meaningful/testing the correct thing.

Clearly these timeout tests need rewriting. Some can switch to use `Awaitability`. Others don't seem to fit the patterns provided. They are expecting exceptions after a certain time has elapsed while some work is being done.

"serialization" is UK English as well.

The rule isn't as simple as "ise"=UK/"ize"=US.

In the UK, it depends on the root of the word (latin/greek/modern) and also the dictionary preference.

Thanks for the clarification. The problem is that the predicate is geo:hasSerialization in the vocabulary, but the error message was mentioning geo:hasSerialisation. I thought the cause of the problem was related to UK English vs. US English.

@Claudenw The JDBC libraries are coded against the SLF4J API.  However unlike most other Jena code the driver JARs often end up used standalone and dynamically loaded by arbitrary JDBC applications.

This means users often don't have the same opportunity to add their preferred logging framework that they normally would when using Jena libraries in a traditional Java application where those would just be one dependency amongst many.  Providing a default logging implementation in the drivers makes it easier for users to get useful logging out of them without any need to re-pack or re-compile the drivers since they can just provide a Log4j 2 configuration file at the JVM level.
@afs Thanks for catching that, weirdly that test was still passing locally

Because this external change breaks our build, I've merged it now.

This PR can still be reviewed and refined.

Key points:

1. If the query does not have any RDF-star related syntax, processing is the normal path. Each of the three RDF-star point (in-memory, TDB1, TDB2) starts with an "if" that sees whether RDF-star processing is needed.
2. The test suite does run for general, TIM, TDB1, and TDB2 datasets if the redirection to RDF-star processing is off.
3. Some processing interfaces have changed: additional to ExprVisitor, removals from algebra visit and transform (due to taking out the old RDF* mode behaviour). This partially accounts for the large number of files.
A good chance to try to read the latest w3c draft, go through some points, and see if I can get my Jena project to build and run from `main` locally. No worry if it's merged before :+1:

Hopefully not too much because there is a reasonable sized and growing test suite.

I think this is the state of the discussions on #872.

The MacOS subjob is unreliable - it works sometimes, usually when the system is quiet. It fails in the same place on a timeout. It takes a lot longer than the Linux job.

I suspect that the machines used are very slow to due high usage. 

To make progress, I suggest we get this PR in to get the Windows build working and begin to split the work into separate jobs.

The project isn't yet depending on github actions to succeed, or not. The jenkins suite of jobs covers several JDKs, and Windows. No MacOS coverage but one pass sometime on GH actions is enough to show that the code works.

Separately, we can tune the timeouts for MacOS somehow and get it working.
Sorry - wrong branch PR.

See PR #954 which I hope is cautious step to get the Transactional interface extended so it is in Jena 4.0.0.

An alternative design with `TxnTrait` (the default methods added separately) might be better. This leaves `Transaction` cleaner as an implementation API.
Continued on #954.

Sorry this has gone on for so long.

I went back to this and investigated the relationship to jena-text. It's hard to untangle because jena-text is involved in the transaction and coordinates with Lucene.

The contract for DatasetChanges is rather unclear - it predates full transaction support for all datasets.

I've raised [JENA-2071](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JENA-2071) to deprecate `DatasetChanges` so it can be removed from general use, freeing up space to do an "outside" transaction monitor with new, definite contract.

If this is still relevant, or you have further thoughts, please add to the ticket [JENA-1656](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JENA-1656).
(user error)

Sorry this has gone on for so long.

I've raised [JENA-2071](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JENA-2071) to deprecate `DatasetChanges` so it can be removed from general use, freeing up space to do an "outside" transaction monitor with new, definite contract.

If this is still relevant, or you have further thoughts, please add to the ticket [JENA-1656](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JENA-1656).

Rebased, and updated JS dependencies (found no security issues). Had to pin sass-loader due to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/66082397/typeerror-this-getoptions-is-not-a-function (I have the same in a project at $work). Vue 3 is almost fully production ready, with a few dependencies needing to add support to this new version. That should improve performance (which doesn't seem to be a problem honestly, it's quite fast already), fixes other bugs, but may require some changes in the code (which I'll have to do at $work anyway). But dependency issues like this might disappear when we update :+1:

I'm sorry this has taken so long. I was "out of the loop" for an extended period.

The conflict seems rather small yet causes some tools to get confused over it. I munged a patch locally and it seems fine.

Given this is Jena 4.0.0, would it be better to drop "sparql.function.js"?

Does any of the documentation change? https://jena.apache.org/documentation/query/javascript-functions.html

Added to notes for release notes

The ones removed are "x-" and "text/nquads" (as ASCII, not UTF-8), none of which were ever formalised. I don't know of any client software that uses them. The RFC definition of "text/*" has morphed away from ASCII.  The yukky text/plain for N-triples is still there (RDF 1.0).

My guess is that Java11 with the removal of JDK-provided packages is the most likely user issue and its not even a Jena issue.

But expect the unexpected.

PS If something is in common use, we can put it back at 4.0.1.

The branch marks the transition to java11 which is the trigger for Jena4. Jena4 is not radically different.

OK, I'll reapply the changes to jena3 branch and resubmit a pull request.

As a project we have never committed to maintaining more than one major version.  We simply don't have the volunteer manpower to actively maintain multiple branches like other corporate backed big name ASF projects can.

Our aim has always been to encourage people to migrate forward to the latest supported version.  Yes there will always be folks who don't/can't upgrade in a timely fashion but we don't have any control over that.  The past response to "this is broken in this old version" has always been "have you tried the latest?"

The code has been that (wrong) way for a very, very long time (pre-Apache).

@Claudenw - Are you talking about projects which are fixed to Java8 by their IT environment? Would such projects upgrade anyway? Can they do a local build?

Jena4 isn't that different. 
The Jena3 branch stopped at Feb 8th and so has no general fixes since then. It does include the start of IRIx.
This container change and the rename of RDFWriter/RDFReader interfaces are the only Model API changes.

Jena 4.0.0 builds with Java8 in the cautious rollout, as discussed.

If we keep support at the pace of the slowest downstream project (whoever theyare), we need more people-time to maintain the codebase. Time has gone on making sure it is forward-compatible, with build infrastructure to check.

As @rvesse says - we need to match supply and demand. We carefully evolve. So far, that has worked well.

Possibly because of change of branch to 'main', the Github UI won't merge this.

PR #967 is a command line merge and resolution of this PR.

It then removes the "js" packages since for 4.0.0 we have the opportunity to make braking changes - because the common-case translation to native value types and back is unchanged, only the detailed access of `NodeValue`, the impact should be limited (I don't recall any mention of it in email or JITA tickets).

@strangepleasures - thank you.

That was an automated close by github because the target branch has gone away.

I hope we can incorporate this - there seem to be two parts : building a docker image with SNAPSHOTS and building for the Fuseki/UI version of Fuseki.

Added a commit.

I made the mistake of looking and pulling on the loose thread of whether the TriX writer properly writes with prefixes safely. Writing `<qname>` is disabled but the code should work is enabled.

It is disabled because the regularity of no use of `<qname>` is more useful than space saving, which are small. The TriX writer is streaming and prefixes in-stream can't be handled anyway.

There wasn't a test for reading with xmlns and `<qname>` - test added.

Probably needs @afs to review

Hi there,

Which version of Jena is this about and is it the Fuseki packaging for the standalone server with UI?
What goes wrong?

There was a problem in Jena 3.17.0 (and only that version) : [JENA-2072](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JENA-2072) (related [JENA-2011](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JENA-2011)).

Upgrading components, (presumably Jetty, which is used for that form of Fuseki) made it go away but we didn't find the root cause.
`[::1]` should become `[0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1]` but I, for one, am not clear which component is responsible for converting to canonical form. We can add this to be robust anyway.

I am actually using an older version, but went looking into source code if it has been fixed in latest code. 
**Symptom**: Could not browse dataset in the UI because `http://localhost:3030/$/server` was returning 403. It worked well in Firefox but not in Chrome. When examining the remote address in chrome developer tools, the address appeared to be shortened to `[::1]`

Comparison of firefox / chrome in the attached image 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4743002/113892985-7bb56d00-97be-11eb-85d3-5187aa57b052.png)

@sparkhi -- that is the same details as [JENA-2011](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JENA-2011). That will have affected earlier versions than 3.17.0 and which added "[...]" form.

I have just tried in Chrome, with Jena 4.0.0 and when I see `[::1]:3030` in a request, and it is correctly being let through to localhost only operations by `[0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1]`

`[::1]` is just a way of writing `[0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1]` - it is not a different address -- `::` is "fill as many '0:' as needed to get the right length".

Would it be possible to try Jena 4.0.0? It would be good to pindown what is really happening even when applying the patch. If it is still broken we may need a x.x.1 release.

@afs changes applied. Thank you for the quick response.
I also figured that if you all were ok with this change. I might submit another for `/$/backups-list` and `/$/backup/*`, I just don't have an immediate need for it right now is all.

> not sure how long the compact action may take?

@kinow in my situation, it takes about 18-20 minutes to complete because I have a very large dataset. From what I could tell, there is no way to determine if the process has completed unless you ping the server `/$/tasks/{taskId}` endpoint to check if is finished. I would imagine that continuously pinging that from the front-end wouldn't be very desirable. One could check once on load of some page component though.

I've added a second commit to add the `/$/tasks` endpoint as well. I didn't put it in a separate PR because it seems to make sense to have it added when `/$/compact/*` is added since you can't actually ever check the status of your compact process without it. It still has an opt-in separate from compact though.

> > not sure how long the compact action may take?
> 
> @kinow in my situation, it takes about 18-20 minutes to complete because I have a very large dataset. From what I could tell, there is no way to determine if the process has completed unless you ping the server `/$/tasks/{taskId}` endpoint to check if is finished. I would imagine that continuously pinging that from the front-end wouldn't be very desirable. One could check once on load of some page component though.

I think that's what happens with the backup task (I think it's around [this function](https://github.com/apache/jena/blob/31dc0d328c4858401e5d3fa99702c97eba0383a0/jena-fuseki2/jena-fuseki-webapp/src/main/webapp/js/app/views/dataset-management.js#L144-L153) that is [scheduled](https://github.com/apache/jena/blob/31dc0d328c4858401e5d3fa99702c97eba0383a0/jena-fuseki2/jena-fuseki-webapp/src/main/webapp/js/app/models/task.js#L79-L83) to run [every 500ms or 1s I think](https://github.com/apache/jena/blob/31dc0d328c4858401e5d3fa99702c97eba0383a0/jena-fuseki2/jena-fuseki-webapp/src/main/webapp/js/app/models/task.js#L91-L99).

But that happens only when you execute the backup action. And if you refresh the screen that's gone, you have no more access to the task progress.

In the branch where I am porting it to Vue, I am setting a permanent view for tasks that [updates every 10 seconds](https://github.com/kinow/jena/blob/7580da22cab35b6fbf76006c10544eeba851d84d/jena-fuseki2/jena-fuseki-ui/src/views/manage/Tasks.vue#L118-L126).

But my intention is to first have a replacement for Fuseki Backbone.js app, and then discuss the possibility of perhaps having a secure WebSockets that sends the data to the UI when available. This way we remove the polling, and can send information about any kind of server management tasks to the UI - so I think in the future we could show back up, compression, and other kinds of tasks if that would save users of having to log in to servers and run commands, or having to save HTTP requests to submit to the server.

@bsara -- yes, please. That would be great.
Is there a schedule for releases on this project? I.E. when can I expect to see a production jena with these changes?

The Jena project aims for a release every 3-4 months.

The project operates a "green main branch" - the development main branch is releasable unless there is special reason why it is not in a fit state. There is no special preparation needed other than set the version number.

You are welcome to clone the repo and build the code ("mvn clean install").

As an Apache project, any release by the project is subject to a vote by the PMC. At least 3 PMC members need to vote. This is important because a formal release is transfer from any development build (which is "personal" - it has no standing as a Apache release) to one released by the Apache Software Foundation. The Release Manager is not personally legally liable.

On this issue, we need to decide on access control, or not. These functions are open. As a principle, we need to take these security issues seriously. In some environments, the network/VM/container setup means that serves are not generally accessible but that isn't universal.

One way is restrict to localhost. Another is have a admin/password.

If you want an advance, non-release, build of RDF Delta with development Fuseki, then that is for discussion on RDF Delta. (It is a matter of setting the Jena version but SNAPSHOTS for dependencies can't be released to maven central.)
